skill.name: frontend-dev-guidelines
skill.description: Frontend development guidelines for Next.js + React 19 + shadcn/ui applications. Modern patterns including App Router, Server Components, Client Components, Server Actions, shadcn/ui with Tailwind CSS, React Hook Form, lazy loading, Suspense boundaries, Supabase client integration, performance optimization, and TypeScript best practices. Use when creating pages, components, forms, styling, data fetching, or working with Next.js/React code.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation/skill file with no executable code, no scripts, no network calls, no file system access beyond its own markdown files, no environment variable access, and no command execution. This is a safe knowledge base for frontend development guidance.

content.value_statement: Writing modern frontend code with Next.js, React 19, and shadcn/ui requires understanding Server Components, data fetching patterns, and performance optimization. This skill provides comprehensive guidelines and proven patterns for building type-safe, performant web applications.
actual_capabilities: Create pages and components using Next.js 14+ App Router architecture
Implement Server Components by default with strategic Client Component usage
Build forms with React Hook Form + Zod validation patterns
Fetch data with TanStack Query and Suspense boundaries for optimal UX
Style components with shadcn/ui and Tailwind CSS patterns
Optimize performance using lazy loading, memoization, and code splitting
limitations: Does not generate complete project scaffolding or configuration files
Does not install dependencies or run build commands
Does not access external APIs or databases directly
Does not modify user project files without explicit prompts

use_cases.title: Learn modern Next.js patterns
use_cases.description: Get guidance on Server Components, Server Actions, and App Router architecture for Next.js projects

use_cases.title: Build type-safe applications
use_cases.description: Apply TypeScript best practices with strict typing, prop interfaces, and utility types across your codebase

use_cases.title: Optimize component performance
use_cases.description: Implement lazy loading, Suspense boundaries, and memoization patterns for faster, more responsive UIs

prompt_templates.title: Create new page
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a new dashboard page with data fetching
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new page at app/dashboard/page.tsx that fetches user data using Server Component pattern. Include loading.tsx and error.tsx with proper Suspense boundaries.

prompt_templates.title: Build form component
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a login form component using React Hook Form with Zod validation. Show how to handle form state, error messages, and submission with proper TypeScript types.

prompt_templates.title: Optimize data fetching
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to implement cache-first data fetching with TanStack Query. Include query keys organization, cache invalidation, and optimistic update patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Add shadcn component
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a shadcn/ui Card component with custom styling using Tailwind CSS. Show proper imports, props usage, and responsive design patterns.

output_examples.input: Create a new feature component that displays a list of posts with search functionality
output:
- Use React.FC pattern with typed props interface
- Fetch data with useSuspenseQuery in a child component
- Wrap in SuspenseLoader at the parent level
- Add search state with useDebounce for performance
- Implement cache-first strategy to reuse list data
- Include proper loading and error states
- Use shadcn/ui components (Card, Input, Button)
- Apply Tailwind CSS for responsive styling

best_practices: Use Server Components by default; add 'use client' only when hooks or events are needed
Wrap all async components in SuspenseLoader to prevent layout shift and ensure smooth UX
Define explicit TypeScript interfaces for all props; avoid 'any' type entirely
anti_patterns: Using 'use client' on every component; this defeats Next.js SSR benefits
Early return patterns for loading states; use Suspense boundaries instead
Skipping TypeScript types; rely on type inference only

faq.question: Does this skill work with React 18 or older versions?
faq.answer: The patterns focus on React 19 features like Server Components. Some patterns work with React 18 but Server Components require React 19+.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with Vue or Angular projects?
faq.answer: The skill is Next.js-specific but the principles (SSR patterns, type safety, performance) apply to other frameworks with adaptation.

faq.question: Does this skill create new project files?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides patterns and code examples. You must copy examples into your project files manually.

faq.question: Is my code and data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a read-only knowledge skill that provides guidance. It never accesses your files, environment variables, or network resources.

faq.question: Can I combine this skill with backend development skills?
faq.answer: Yes. It integrates well with backend-dev-guidelines for full-stack Supabase projects.

faq.question: What if I need patterns not covered in the skill?
faq.answer: Ask Claude to generate examples following the documented patterns. The skill includes comprehensive resources for common scenarios.
